questions.question_text: A network administrator needs to keep track of the locations of installed network equipment. Which of the following would be the BEST method to accomplish this task?

comments.content: The question makes sense. You placed the "period" after locations, that's not how the sentence is worded. They want to keep track of the locations OF THE INSTALLED NETWORK EQUIPMENT. Video surveillance does not track equipment or locations.

discussion.content: this is a poorly worded question. The question states they want to keep track of locations. If that is the case then the answer should be video surveillance. If they want to keep track of devices then yes, the answer should be asset tags. Please revise the wording of this question.

questions.question_text: A security team needs to restrict access to a wireless network in a certain area. Which of the following would be used to enforce this restriction?

discussion.content: geofencing - limits wireless area coverage to a certain area

questions.question_text:
A network engineer is hardening the security of a remote office. The firewall at this location needs to remain accessible for remote management by technicians.
The firewall vendor advises disabling port 443 from WAN-facing access. In addition to disabling port 443, which of the following can the engineer do to MOST effectively balance the remote connectivity and security needs for this site?

discussion.content: Can someone explain this? I thought RDP was a remote desktop protocol. I am connecting to a firewall by using this? IPSec uses port 500 and it is a secure method of connecting.

comments.content: Also they did ask for security right ? RDP doesn't sound secure to me.
You are correct! It can be used to connect a Linux or Unix computer to a windows host but not the other way around. Answer IMHO is IPSec.

discussion.content: If you have an IPSec tunnel, you could get to 443 via the tunnel to an internal facing IP. Thus you aren't using 443 on a WAN facing interface. That's my choice.

Selected Answer: A
IPSec for me was the best answer... They did close HTTPS port 443. So I mean the answer is sort of right for the most part.
I guess the key word here is "balance". So RDP would be right. IPSEC would be the best security answer but not balance remote with security...
IPSec is the only logical answer to this one.
I thought the answer was "A. Enable an IPSec tunnel."

comments.content: Even when you use RDP on something like a Linux or Unix OS itâ€™s for only connecting to a Windows machine. IE: to connect a Linux computer to a windows computer not the other way around.

discussion.content:
Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) is a proprietary protocol developed by Microsoft which provides a user with a graphical interface to connect to another computer over a network connection.[1] The user employs RDP client software for this purpose, while the other computer must run RDP server software.

Clients exist for most versions of Microsoft Windows (including Windows Mobile), Linux, Unix, macOS, iOS, Android, and other operating systems. RDP servers are built into Windows operating systems; an RDP server for Unix and OS X also exists.

choices.B: Enable RDP access to the firewall.
choices.D: Enable Telnet access to the firewall.

questions.question_text: Ann, a user, is attempting to charge her phone using the USB port of her computer. She realizes the port has been disabled. Which of the following policies would restrict the use of the USB port?

discussion.content: Hey guys when the net admins disabled the computer port they didn't have in mind "Oh lets disable this port so workers can't charge their phones on it." I mean this is ridiculous charging your phone isn't the focus of a BYOD. It it MUCH more likely the AUP says "do not inject portable storage drives into the computer because this could put us at risk of data prevention." You know like plugging a USB to steal data? BYOD makes no sense if thought about this for more than 10 seconds
key word = USB port of her computer

comments.content: It says 'her phone'. Doesnt say its a personal phone could be her work phone. AUP for me

discussion.content: Thats correct, It never states the use of a buisness laptop. infact its says "her laptop" BYOD would be a correct.

"The USB Charging feature is disabled by default, so if you wish to use a USB port to charge a device, the feature must first be enabled." So, she doesn't want to use her cell phone. She is just charging. This is not BYOD, This AUB of the business laptop, which can't be used as a charger or for data transfer.

comments.content:
The AUP defines what is and what is not acceptable to do on an organization's computers.
 -Ownership: Equipment and any proprietary information stored on the organization's computers are the property of the organization.
 -Network Access: Users will access only information they are authorized to access.
 -Privacy/Consent to Monitoring: Anything users do on an organization's computers is not private.
 -Illegal Use: No one may use an organization's computers for anything that breaks the law.
- Page 629, Network+, Mike Meyers

From reading the above, AUP seems to focus on activity/use once in the device. BYOD focuses on what personnel can/can't do with their personal devices (i.e. the scenario here).
Because VNC fits better in this case. RDP is mostly recommended for Windows as is developed by Microsoft. VNC is platform-independent.

questions.question_text: A technician needs to manage a Linux-based system from the GUI remotely. Which of the following technologies should the technician deploy?
